docs.title: ARP
docs.text: (What ARP is, how it works, and how to use ARP commands)

docs.title: 1. Why ARP Exists (The Core Problem)
docs.text:
On a local network (LAN):

  • IP address → used by software (Layer 3)
  • MAC address → used by network hardware (Layer 2)

👉 Ethernet does NOT understand IP addresses 👉 IP packets must be delivered using MAC addresses

So the question is:

If I know a device’s IP address, how do I find its MAC address?

That is exactly what ARP does.

docs.title: 2. What Is ARP?
docs.text:
ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps:

IP address  →  MAC address

Example:

192.168.1.1 → aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff

It works only inside a local network (same subnet).

docs.title: 3. ARP Works at Which Layer?
docs.text:
Layer Name ARP Role Layer 2 Data Link Uses MAC addresses Layer 3 Network Uses IP addresses

🔹 ARP is between Layer 2 and Layer 3 🔹 It connects IP logic with Ethernet reality

docs.title: 4. How ARP Works (Step by Step)
docs.text:
Assume:

  • Your computer: 192.168.1.10
  • Router: 192.168.1.1
  • You want to send data to the router

docs.title: Step 1: Check ARP Cache
docs.text:
Your system checks:

Do I already know the MAC for 192.168.1.1?
  • Yes → send packet directly
  • No → continue to Step 2

docs.title: Step 2: Send ARP Request (Broadcast)
docs.text:
Your computer broadcasts:

Who has 192.168.1.1?
Tell 192.168.1.10
  • Destination MAC: ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
  • Everyone in the LAN receives it

docs.title: Step 3: ARP Reply (Unicast)
docs.text:
The router replies:

192.168.1.1 is at aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff

docs.title: Step 4: Save to ARP Cache
docs.text:
Your system stores:

192.168.1.1 → aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff

Next time, no broadcast is needed.

docs.title: 5. What Is the ARP Cache?
docs.text:
The ARP cache is a temporary table in memory:

IP Address MAC Address Interface 192.168.1.1 aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff eth0
  • Entries expire automatically
  • Prevents repeated broadcasts
  • Speeds up communication

docs.title: 6.1 ip neigh (Recommended, Modern)
docs.text:
ip neigh

Example output:

192.168.1.1 dev eth0 lladdr aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff REACHABLE

Fields:

  • dev → network interface
  • lladdr → MAC address
  • REACHABLE / STALE / DELAY → state

🔹 This is the modern replacement for arp

docs.title: 6.2 arp (Legacy but Still Common)
docs.text:
arp -n

Example:

Address          HWtype  HWaddress           Iface
192.168.1.1      ether   aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff   eth0

Options:

  • -n → numeric output (no DNS lookup)

docs.title: 6.3 Add a Static ARP Entry (Rare but Useful)
docs.text:
sudo arp -s 192.168.1.100 00:11:22:33:44:55

Meaning:

  • Manually bind IP → MAC
  • Entry does not expire

⚠️ Be careful: wrong entries break networking

docs.title: 6.4 Delete an ARP Entry
docs.text:
sudo arp -d 192.168.1.1

Or using ip:

sudo ip neigh del 192.168.1.1 dev eth0

docs.title: Using ping
docs.text:
ping 192.168.1.1
  • If MAC unknown → ARP request happens automatically
  • After ping, check cache again

docs.title: 8. ARP States Explained
docs.text:
State Meaning REACHABLE Recently confirmed STALE Old but usable DELAY Checking if still valid FAILED No response

Seen via:

ip neigh

docs.title: 1️⃣ Debug network connectivity
docs.text: “Why can’t I reach the gateway?”

docs.title: 2️⃣ Find devices in local network
docs.text: “Who is using this IP?”

docs.title: 3️⃣ Understand network attacks
docs.text: ARP spoofing / ARP poisoning

docs.title: 10. ARP Security (Beginner Awareness)
docs.text:
ARP has no authentication.

This allows attacks like:

  • ARP Spoofing
  • Man-in-the-Middle

Example idea:

Attacker lies: “I am the router”

Defenses (advanced topics):

  • Static ARP
  • DHCP snooping
  • Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI)

docs.title: 11. Quick Summary
docs.text:
• ARP maps IP → MAC
  • Works only in local networks
  • Uses broadcast requests
  • Results are stored in ARP cache
  • Key commands:
    • ip neigh
    • arp -n
    • arp -s
    • arp -d

docs.title: 1. What Is a Bypass Router?
docs.text:
A bypass router is a secondary router placed between your main router and the internet (or inside your network) that:

  • Only processes specific traffic (for example, traffic that needs a proxy or special routing)
  • Lets all other traffic bypass it directly to the main router or ISP

In simple terms:

Some traffic goes through the “special router”, the rest goes normally.

docs.title: 2. Why Use a Bypass Router?
docs.text: Beginners usually use a bypass router for these reasons:

docs.title: 2.1 Stability
docs.text:
• Your main router stays clean and stable
  • If the bypass router fails, the main network still works

docs.title: 2.2 Device Isolation
docs.text:
• Only certain devices use proxy / special routing
  • Other devices are unaffected

docs.title: 2.3 Easy Management
docs.text:
• No need to install complex plugins on the main router
  • Easier to test, reset, or replace

docs.title: 3. Typical Use Cases
docs.text: Use Case Explanation Proxy / scientific routing Only selected traffic goes through proxy Testing OpenWrt / LEDE Avoid breaking your main router Multi-network setup Office / lab / IoT separation Gaming or streaming Keep latency-sensitive traffic clean

docs.title: 4.1 Most Common Topology (Recommended)
docs.text:
Internet
   │
Main Router (ISP Router)
   │
Bypass Router (OpenWrt / LEDE)
   │
PC / Phone / TV
  • Main router handles:
    • PPPoE / DHCP
    • Wi-Fi for normal devices
  • Bypass router handles:
    • Proxy
    • Policy routing

docs.title: 4.2 Parallel Connection (Advanced)
docs.text:
Internet
   │
Main Router
 ┌─┴─────────┐
Normal LAN   Bypass Router
               │
          Special Devices

This is not recommended for beginners.

docs.title: 5.1 Router Requirements
docs.text:
Minimum recommended specs:

  • CPU: Any modern SoC (MT7621, IPQ40xx, etc.)
  • RAM: 128 MB or more
  • Flash: 16 MB or more
  • Ethernet ports: At least 2

Popular beginner-friendly models:

  • GL.iNet MT300N-V2
  • GL.iNet MT1300
  • Xiaomi AX series (with OpenWrt support)

docs.title: 6. Software Choices
docs.text:
Most bypass routers run:

  • OpenWrt
  • LEDE (older fork, concept is the same)

Common routing/proxy solutions:

  • OpenClash
  • PassWall
  • SSR Plus

docs.title: Step 1: Flash OpenWrt / LEDE
docs.text:
• Flash firmware via:
    • Vendor UI
    • Breed Web
    • U-Boot (advanced)

After flashing:

  • Access router at 192.168.1.1

docs.title: WAN Interface
docs.text:
• Connect bypass router WAN to main router LAN
  • Set WAN to:
    • DHCP client (most common)

docs.title: LAN Interface
docs.text:
• Use a different subnet than main router

Example:

  • Main router: 192.168.1.1
  • Bypass router: 192.168.2.1

This avoids IP conflicts.

docs.title: Step 3: Disable Unnecessary Features (Optional)
docs.text:
If main router already handles Wi-Fi:

  • Disable Wi-Fi on bypass router
  • Use wired connection only

docs.title: Step 4: Install Proxy / Routing Plugin
docs.text:
Using LuCI (Web UI):

  1. Open System → Software
  2. Update package lists
  3. Install one of:
    • OpenClash
    • PassWall
    • SSR Plus

docs.title: Step 5: Configure Policy Routing
docs.text:
This is the core idea of a bypass router.

You usually choose one of these modes:

Mode Meaning GFW list Only blocked sites use proxy GeoIP Foreign IPs go through proxy Global All traffic goes through proxy

For beginners:

  • Start with GFW list or GeoIP

docs.title: Step 6: Connect Devices
docs.text:
Devices that should use bypass routing:

  • Connect directly to the bypass router

Devices that should NOT use it:

  • Connect to the main router

docs.title: 8. How Traffic Flows (Simple Explanation)
docs.text:
Example: Phone connected to bypass router

  1. Phone sends request
  2. Bypass router checks rules
  3. If matched:
    • Goes through proxy
  4. If not:
    • Goes directly to main router
  5. Main router sends traffic to ISP

docs.title: 9.1 IP Conflict
docs.text:
• Main router and bypass router use the same LAN IP
  • Fix: Use different subnets

docs.title: 9.2 Wrong Cable Connection
docs.text:
• WAN ↔ LAN confusion
  • Fix: Main router LAN → Bypass router WAN

docs.title: 9.3 DNS Problems
docs.text:
• Websites open slowly or fail
  • Fix:
    • Use reliable DNS
    • Enable fake-IP or redir-host properly

docs.title: 10. How to Test If It Works
docs.text:
• Open a blocked website on:
    • Device connected to bypass router → should work
    • Device connected to main router → should not
  • Check plugin logs
  • Check public IP differences

docs.title: 11. When You Should NOT Use a Bypass Router
docs.text:
• Very limited space or power
  • Only one device needs proxy (client-side app is enough)
  • Ultra-low latency requirements

docs.title: 12. Summary
docs.text:
A bypass router is:

  • A safe
  • flexible
  • beginner-friendly

way to introduce advanced routing without breaking your main network.

Main router stays simple. Bypass router does the heavy work.

docs.title: DDNS
docs.text: DDNS is one of those networking concepts that sounds complex at first, but once you understand the problem it solves, everything clicks.

docs.title: IP addresses change
docs.text:
Most home and small-office Internet connections use a dynamic public IP address.

That means:

  • Today your public IP might be 203.0.113.25
  • Tomorrow it might become 203.0.113.89
  • You don’t control when it changes

This creates a problem:

How can others always find your server if its IP keeps changing?

docs.title: 2. What Is DDNS?
docs.text:
DDNS (Dynamic DNS) automatically keeps a domain name pointing to your current public IP address.

In simple terms:

DDNS = a domain name that follows your changing IP

docs.title: 3. DNS vs DDNS
docs.text: Feature DNS DDNS IP address Usually static Changes frequently Updates Manual Automatic Typical users Websites, companies Home users, labs, servers Use case Public services Home servers, remote access

docs.title: 4. A Real-World Example
docs.text:
Without DDNS:

You → remember IP address → IP changes → connection fails

With DDNS:

you.myhome.net → always updated → always reachable

Your device or router:

  1. Detects IP change
  2. Updates DDNS provider
  3. Domain points to new IP automatically

docs.title: 5. How DDNS Works (Step by Step)
docs.text:
1. You register a domain or subdomain Example: myserver.ddns.net

  2. Your ISP assigns you a public IP Example: 100.64.12.45

  3. A DDNS client runs on:

    • Your router, or
    • A computer/server

  4. When IP changes:

    • Client sends update to DDNS provider
    • DNS record is updated

  5. Users connect using:

    myserver.ddns.net

docs.title: 6. Common DDNS Providers
docs.text:
Popular beginner-friendly DDNS services:

  • No-IP
  • DuckDNS
  • Dynu
  • Cloudflare (via API)
  • Router-built-in DDNS services

Many home routers support DDNS directly.

docs.title: 7. DDNS Client: Where Does It Run?
Option 1: On the Router (Recommended)
docs.text:
• Works even when computers are off
  • Most stable solution

docs.title: Option 2: On a Computer or Server
docs.text:
• Useful if router doesn’t support DDNS
  • Requires system to be always on

docs.title: 1️⃣ Remote Access to Home Server
docs.text:
• NAS
  • Media server
  • Web server
  • Game server

docs.title: 2️⃣ SSH into Home Network
docs.text: ssh user@myhome.ddns.net

docs.title: 3️⃣ VPN Server
docs.text:
• WireGuard
  • OpenVPN
  • Tailscale fallback endpoints

docs.title: 4️⃣ Learning & Labs
docs.text:
• Networking practice
  • Self-hosted services

docs.title: 9. DDNS + Port Forwarding
docs.text:
DDNS alone is not enough.

You also need:

  • Port forwarding on your router

Example:

Service Port SSH 22 HTTP 80 HTTPS 443

Flow:

Internet → Public IP → Router → Local Device

⚠️ Exposing ports requires security awareness.

docs.title: 10. DDNS vs Static IP
docs.text:
Feature DDNS Static IP Cost Free / cheap Often expensive Setup Easy ISP dependent Stability Good Excellent Home use ✅ ❌ (usually unnecessary)

DDNS is the practical choice for most home users.

docs.title: 11. DDNS vs Tailscale / Zero-Trust Tools
docs.text:
Feature DDNS Tailscale Public exposure Yes No Port forwarding Required Not required Security User-managed Built-in Ease of use Medium Very easy

📌 DDNS is classic networking

📌 Tailscale is modern zero-trust networking

Both are useful to learn.

docs.title: 12. Basic Security Tips (Very Important)
docs.text:
✔ Use strong passwords

✔ Prefer HTTPS over HTTP

✔ Avoid exposing unnecessary ports

✔ Change default router credentials

✔ Consider a firewall or VPN

docs.title: 13. Minimal Example Setup (Conceptual)
docs.text:
[ Laptop ] → myserver.ddns.net → [ Router ]
                                     ↓
                               [ Home Server ]

Your domain always resolves to your current public IP.

docs.title: 14. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ Thinking DDNS gives you Internet access

❌ Forgetting port forwarding

❌ Exposing services without security

❌ Running DDNS client on an unstable device

docs.title: 15. Summary
docs.text:
• DDNS solves the changing public IP problem
  • It keeps a domain name updated automatically
  • Works best with router-based clients
  • Often used with port forwarding
  • Essential skill for home labs and self-hosting

docs.title: 1. Start with a Simple Analogy 🚪
docs.text:
Imagine:

  • IP address = a building’s street address
  • Port = a specific door or room inside that building

Your computer may run many services at the same time:

  • a web server
  • an SSH server
  • a database
  • a game server

They all share one IP address, so how does the computer know which service should receive incoming data?

👉 Ports solve this problem.

docs.title: 2. What Is a Port?
docs.text:
A port is a number that identifies a specific application or service on a computer.

  • Range: 0 – 65535
    • $2^16$ = 65536
    • 16 bits
  • Each port can be “listened to” by one service
  • Data sent to an IP + port goes to one exact program

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
IP:   192.168.1.10
Port: 80

Means:

“Send this data to the web server running on this computer.”

docs.title: 3. Why Ports Are Necessary
docs.text:
Without ports:

  • Only one service could run per IP
  • Web + SSH + database would conflict

With ports:

  • Many services coexist safely
Service Port Web (HTTP) 80 Secure Web (HTTPS) 443 SSH 22 FTP 21 MySQL 3306

docs.title: 4. IP Address vs Port (Very Important)
docs.text:
They always come together.

<IP address>:<Port>

Examples:

127.0.0.1:8080
192.168.1.5:22
google.com:443

Think of it as:

City + house number

docs.title: 5. Well-Known Ports (0–1023)
docs.text:
• $2^10 =1024$, 10 bits

These are standard ports, reserved for common services.

Port Service Description 20 / 21 FTP File transfer 22 SSH Remote login 25 SMTP Email sending 53 DNS Domain name resolution 80 HTTP Web (no encryption) 443 HTTPS Web (encrypted)

⚠️ On Linux/macOS:

  • Ports below 1024 usually require root/admin privileges

docs.title: 1024–49151: Registered ports
docs.text: • Used by applications (databases, dev tools)

docs.title: 49152–65535: Dynamic (Ephemeral) ports
docs.text:
• Automatically chosen by the OS
  • Used temporarily by clients

Example:

  • Browser connects to google.com:443
  • Your OS picks a random local port like 53124

docs.title: Server
docs.text:
• Listens on a fixed port
  • Example:
Web server listening on port 80

docs.title: Client
docs.text:
• Uses a random temporary port
  • Example:
Client port: 53124 → Server port: 443

Diagram:

[Your Browser:53124] ---> [Server:443]

docs.title: 8. TCP Ports vs UDP Ports
docs.text: Ports exist for both TCP and UDP, but they behave differently.

docs.title: TCP (Reliable)
docs.text:
• Ordered
  • Retransmits lost data
  • Used by:
    • HTTP/HTTPS
    • SSH
    • FTP

docs.title: UDP (Fast)
docs.text:
• No guarantee of delivery
  • Lower latency
  • Used by:
    • DNS
    • Video streaming
    • Online games

⚠️ Same port number can exist for both TCP and UDP.

docs.title: Open port
docs.text:
• A program is listening
  • Can accept connections

docs.title: Closed port
docs.text:
• No service is listening
  • Connection rejected

Security note:

Fewer open ports = smaller attack surface

docs.title: macOS / Linux
docs.text:
lsof -i :80
netstat -an | grep LISTEN
ss -lnt

docs.title: Windows
docs.text: netstat -ano

docs.title: 11. Port in URLs
docs.text:
Sometimes ports appear in URLs.

http://localhost:3000
http://192.168.1.10:8080
  • http default → port 80
  • https default → port 443
  • Other ports must be specified explicitly

docs.title: 12. Common Beginner Mistakes ❌
docs.text:
1. ❌ Confusing port with IP
  2. ❌ Assuming one port can serve multiple programs
  3. ❌ Forgetting firewall blocks ports
  4. ❌ Using privileged ports without permission
  5. ❌ Exposing services directly to the internet

docs.title: 13. One-Sentence Summary
docs.text: A port is a numbered door on a computer that allows multiple network services to share the same IP address safely.

docs.title: PPPoE
docs.text: (Point-to-Point Protocol over Ethernet)

docs.title: 1. What Is PPPoE?
docs.text:
PPPoE stands for:

Point-to-Point Protocol over Ethernet

It is a network protocol used by many ISPs to:

  • Authenticate users (username & password)
  • Assign IP addresses
  • Manage billing and sessions

In simple terms:

PPPoE lets your ISP know who you are before giving you internet access.

docs.title: 2. Why PPPoE Exists
docs.text:
Originally, ISPs used PPP over dial-up lines. When broadband (DSL / fiber) arrived, ISPs needed:

  • User authentication
  • Per-user accounting
  • Session control

Ethernet alone cannot authenticate users, so PPP was encapsulated inside Ethernet frames.

That combination is PPPoE.

docs.title: 3. Where PPPoE Is Used
docs.text:
Common scenarios:

Access Type Uses PPPoE ADSL Yes VDSL Yes FTTH (fiber) Very common Cable modem Usually no Mobile (4G/5G) No

If your ISP gives you:

  • Username
  • Password

You are almost certainly using PPPoE.

docs.title: Typical Home Setup
docs.text:
Internet
   │
ISP (PPPoE Server)
   │
ONT / Modem (Bridge Mode)
   │
Router (PPPoE Client)
   │
LAN Devices

Key point:

  • Only one device performs PPPoE dialing
  • Usually your main router

docs.title: 5. PPPoE vs DHCP (Important Comparison)
docs.text:
Feature PPPoE DHCP Authentication Yes No Username/Password Required Not needed Session control Yes No Overhead Slightly higher Lower Typical user ISP customers Local networks

Think of it like this:

  • PPPoE → logging into the internet
  • DHCP → getting an IP inside a local network

docs.title: 6. How PPPoE Works (Step by Step)
docs.text: PPPoE has two phases:

docs.title: 6.1 Discovery Phase
docs.text:
Goal: find the ISP’s PPPoE server

Steps:

  1. PADI – Client broadcasts: “Any PPPoE server here?”
  2. PADO – Server replies
  3. PADR – Client requests a session
  4. PADS – Server confirms session ID

At this point:

  • A logical point-to-point link is created

docs.title: 6.2 Session Phase
docs.text:
Now real PPP begins:

  1. LCP – Link parameters negotiation
  2. Authentication
    • PAP (plain)
    • CHAP (challenge-response)
  3. IPCP
    • Assign IP address
    • Set DNS, MTU, etc.

Once complete:

Internet access is established

docs.title: 7. What Information You Need for PPPoE
docs.text:
From your ISP:

  • PPPoE username
  • PPPoE password

Optional:

  • VLAN ID (common in fiber networks)
  • MTU requirement

docs.title: 8. Configuring PPPoE on a Router (Beginner View)
Required Settings
docs.text:
Setting Value WAN protocol PPPoE Username From ISP Password From ISP MTU 1492 (default)

Why MTU = 1492?

  • Ethernet MTU = 1500
  • PPPoE header = 8 bytes
  • 1500 − 8 = 1492

docs.title: Common WAN Modes Explained
docs.text: Mode When to use PPPoE ISP gives account DHCP Cable / shared LAN Static IP Enterprise / special plan Bridge Modem only, router dials

docs.title: Bridge Mode vs Router Mode
docs.text:
Modem Mode Who does PPPoE Bridge Your router Router Modem itself

Best practice:

Modem in bridge mode + router dials PPPoE

This avoids:

  • Double NAT
  • Port forwarding issues

docs.title: 10. PPPoE in OpenWrt / LEDE (Conceptual)
docs.text:
In OpenWrt:

  • PPPoE is a WAN interface protocol
  • pppd handles authentication and session

Key files (advanced):

  • /etc/config/network
  • /etc/ppp/

Beginners should:

  • Use LuCI (web UI)
  • Avoid manual config at first

docs.title: 11.1 PPPoE Dial Fails
docs.text:
Possible reasons:

  • Wrong username/password
  • ISP limits concurrent sessions
  • Wrong VLAN ID
  • ONT not in bridge mode

docs.title: 11.2 Connected but No Internet
docs.text:
Causes:

  • DNS misconfiguration
  • MTU mismatch
  • Firewall blocking

docs.title: 11.3 Frequent Disconnects
docs.text:
Causes:

  • Poor fiber / DSL signal
  • ISP timeout policy
  • Router CPU overload

docs.title: 12. PPPoE Performance Considerations
docs.text:
• PPPoE adds CPU overhead
  • On weak routers:
    • High-speed PPPoE may bottleneck
  • Hardware acceleration may not apply

Rule of thumb:

  • Gigabit PPPoE needs a strong CPU

docs.title: Correct Design
docs.text:
ONT (Bridge)
   │
Main Router (PPPoE)
   │
Bypass Router / AP

docs.title: Wrong Design
docs.text:
ONT
 ├─ Router A (PPPoE)
 └─ Router B (PPPoE) ❌

Most ISPs allow only one PPPoE session.

docs.title: 14. When You Should Care About PPPoE
docs.text:
You should understand PPPoE if you:

  • Flash OpenWrt / LEDE
  • Build bypass router setups
  • Use bridge mode ONT
  • Debug WAN issues

docs.title: 15. Summary
docs.text:
• PPPoE = PPP + Ethernet
  • Used for ISP authentication
  • Requires username & password
  • Usually handled by the main router
  • Still very common in fiber networks

PPPoE is not “old” — it is simply “infrastructure”.

docs.title: 1. Why TLS Exists
docs.text:
Imagine sending a postcard through the mail ✉️ Anyone along the way can:

  • Read it
  • Copy it
  • Modify it

Early Internet traffic worked like that.

TLS fixes this problem by providing:

  1. 🔒 Encryption – others can’t read the data
  2. 🧾 Authentication – you know who you’re talking to
  3. 🛡 Integrity – data can’t be secretly modified

Today, TLS protects:

  • HTTPS (websites)
  • Email (SMTP, IMAP)
  • APIs
  • VPNs
  • Many CLI tools and cloud services

If you see https://, TLS is involved.

docs.title: 2. What Is TLS?
docs.text:
TLS (Transport Layer Security) is a cryptographic protocol that secures communication between two parties, usually:

  • Client (browser, app, CLI tool)
  • Server (website, API, service)

TLS operates between the application layer and the transport layer.

Application (HTTP, SMTP, IMAP)
------------------------------
TLS
------------------------------
TCP
------------------------------
IP

TLS is the modern replacement for SSL (SSL is obsolete).

docs.title: 3.1 Eavesdropping
docs.text:
Without TLS:

password=123456

With TLS:

9f a3 7b 2c 81 ...

docs.title: 3.2 Man-in-the-Middle Attacks
docs.text:
TLS ensures:

  • You are really talking to google.com
  • Not an attacker pretending to be it

docs.title: 3.3 Data Tampering
docs.text: TLS detects if data was modified in transit.

docs.title: 4. TLS in One Picture
docs.text:
Client                    Server
  | ------ ClientHello ---> |
  | <----- ServerHello ---- |
  | <--- Certificate ------ |
  | ---- Key Exchange ----> |
  | === Encrypted Data ===  |

This initial process is called the TLS Handshake.

docs.title: *5. The TLS Handshake (Step by Step)
docs.text: Let’s simplify what really happens.

docs.title: Step 1: ClientHello
docs.text:
The client says:

  • TLS versions it supports
  • Encryption algorithms it supports
  • A random number

docs.title: Step 2: ServerHello
docs.text:
The server replies:

  • Chosen TLS version
  • Chosen encryption algorithm
  • Its own random number
  • Certificate

docs.title: Step 3: Certificate Verification
docs.text:
The client:

  • Checks the server certificate
  • Verifies it was signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA)

If this fails → connection aborted ❌

docs.title: Step 4: Key Exchange
docs.text:
Both sides:

  • Agree on a shared secret
  • No one else can compute it

(Modern TLS uses ECDHE for this.)

docs.title: Step 5: Secure Communication
docs.text:
All further data is:

  • Encrypted
  • Authenticated
  • Integrity-protected

docs.title: 6. Certificates Explained Simply
docs.text:
A TLS certificate binds:

Public Key ↔ Domain Name

Issued by a Certificate Authority (CA) like:

  • Let’s Encrypt
  • DigiCert
  • GlobalSign

Your OS/browser trusts a list of CAs.

docs.title: Certificate Chain
docs.text:
Your Site
  ↓
Intermediate CA
  ↓
Root CA (trusted by OS)

docs.title: 7. Symmetric vs Asymmetric Encryption
docs.text: TLS uses both.

docs.title: Asymmetric Encryption (Slow)
docs.text:
• Public key / private key
  • Used for:
    • Authentication
    • Key exchange

docs.title: Symmetric Encryption (Fast)
docs.text:
• One shared secret key
  • Used for:
    • Actual data transfer

TLS combines them:

Asymmetric to agree on a key, symmetric to send data.

docs.title: 8. Common TLS Versions
docs.text:
Version Status SSL 2.0 ❌ Broken SSL 3.0 ❌ Broken TLS 1.0 ❌ Deprecated TLS 1.1 ❌ Deprecated TLS 1.2 ✅ Widely used TLS 1.3 ✅ Modern & faster

TLS 1.3 improves:

  • Faster handshake
  • Better security defaults
  • Fewer insecure options

docs.title: 9. HTTPS = HTTP + TLS
docs.text:
HTTP   → Plain text
HTTPS  → HTTP over TLS

What HTTPS gives you:

  • 🔒 Encrypted traffic
  • 🧾 Verified website identity
  • 🛡 Protection against tampering

What it does not give you:

  • A “safe” website
  • Protection from malware
  • Anonymity

docs.title: Check a TLS connection
docs.text: openssl s_client -connect google.com:443

docs.title: See certificate details
docs.text: openssl x509 -in cert.pem -text -noout

docs.title: Test supported TLS versions
docs.text: curl -v https://example.com

docs.title: “TLS encrypts everything on the server”
docs.text:
❌ No

TLS only protects data in transit, not at rest.

docs.title: “TLS makes a website trustworthy”
docs.text:
❌ No

It only proves domain ownership, not intent.

docs.title: “SSL and TLS are the same”
docs.text: ❌ SSL is obsolete; TLS is the correct term.

docs.title: 12. Where You’ll See TLS
docs.text:
• Browsers (HTTPS)
  • Git over HTTPS
  • Docker registries
  • Email servers
  • APIs
  • Cloud services
  • Tailscale, VPNs, proxies

If security matters, TLS is there.

docs.title: 13. Mental Model to Remember
docs.text:
Think of TLS as:

A locked, tamper-proof, identity-verified tunnel between your computer and a server.

docs.title: 14. What to Learn Next
docs.text:
If you want to go deeper:

  • How certificates are issued (ACME / Let’s Encrypt)
  • TLS 1.3 handshake in detail
  • Cipher suites
  • Mutual TLS (mTLS)
  • TLS in Nginx / Caddy

docs.title: 1. What Is TUN Mode?
docs.text:
TUN mode is a networking technique that works at the IP layer (Layer 3).

  • It creates a virtual network interface
  • This interface sends and receives IP packets
  • Applications think they are using a real network card, but the data is actually handled by software

👉 In short: TUN = virtual IP tunnel

docs.title: 2. TUN vs Real Network Interface
docs.text:
Real NIC (eth0, wlan0) TUN Interface (tun0) Physical hardware Software-only Sends Ethernet frames Sends IP packets Connected to cables / Wi-Fi Connected to a program

Example:

eth0  -> real Ethernet card
wlan0 -> Wi-Fi card
tun0  -> virtual tunnel interface

docs.title: 3. Why Do We Need TUN Mode?
docs.text:
TUN mode is mainly used to:

  • Build VPNs
  • Redirect traffic
  • Simulate networks
  • Implement custom routing or encryption

Typical use cases:

  • OpenVPN (TUN mode)
  • WireGuard
  • Shadowsocks VPN mode
  • Network experiments and labs

docs.title: Step-by-step idea
docs.text:
1. The OS creates a TUN interface (e.g. tun0)
  2. Applications send IP packets to tun0
  3. The kernel forwards packets to a user-space program
  4. The program:
    • encrypts / modifies / encapsulates packets
    • sends them over a real network (TCP/UDP)
  5. On the other side:
    • packets are decoded
    • injected back into another TUN interface

docs.title: 5. Simple Diagram
docs.text:
Application
    |
    |  IP Packet
    v
  tun0 (virtual)
    |
    |  read() / write()
    v
VPN Program (user space)
    |
    |  encrypted UDP/TCP
    v
Internet

docs.title: 6. TUN vs TAP (Very Important)
docs.text:
Feature TUN TAP OSI Layer Layer 3 (IP) Layer 2 (Ethernet) Data type IP packets Ethernet frames Supports ARP ❌ No ✅ Yes Common use VPN routing VPN bridging

Memory tip:

  • TUN = IP tunnel
  • TAP = Ethernet bridge

docs.title: 7. What Does a TUN Packet Look Like?
docs.text:
In TUN mode, packets are pure IP packets:

[ IP Header ][ TCP/UDP ][ Data ]

No Ethernet header:

❌ No MAC address
❌ No ARP

That’s why TUN is lighter and faster for routing-based VPNs.

docs.title: 8. Example: OpenVPN TUN Mode
docs.text:
When OpenVPN runs in TUN mode:

  1. Creates tun0

  2. Assigns an IP (e.g. 10.8.0.2)

  3. Changes routing table:

    default route -> tun0

  4. All traffic goes into the tunnel

docs.title: List interfaces
docs.text:
ip addr

Example output:

tun0: <POINTOPOINT,MULTICAST,NOARP,UP>
    inet 10.8.0.2/24

docs.title: Check routes
docs.text: ip route

docs.title: 10. Why TUN Is Preferred for VPNs
docs.text:
Advantages:

  • ✅ Simple
  • ✅ Fast
  • ✅ Works well with routing
  • ✅ No Ethernet overhead
  • ✅ Easy to scale

Disadvantages:

  • ❌ Cannot do LAN broadcast
  • ❌ No Layer 2 protocols

docs.title: 11. When Should You Use TUN Mode?
docs.text:
Use TUN mode when:

  • You only care about IP traffic
  • You want a VPN
  • You don’t need Ethernet bridging
  • You want better performance

Use TAP mode when:

  • You need LAN-like behavior
  • You need broadcasts or ARP

docs.title: 12. Beginner Summary
docs.text:
• TUN creates a virtual IP interface
  • Works at Layer 3
  • Handles IP packets only
  • Commonly used in VPNs
  • Faster and simpler than TAP

If you remember only one sentence: TUN mode = software network card for IP packets

docs.title: Wi-Fi
docs.text: Wi-Fi is everywhere—homes, schools, cafés, offices—but many beginners use it every day without really understanding how it works. This tutorial explains what Wi-Fi is, how it works, and how to use it properly, step by step.

docs.title: 1. What Is Wi-Fi?
docs.text:
Wi-Fi is a technology that allows devices to connect to a local network wirelessly using radio waves.

With Wi-Fi, your devices can:

  • Access the Internet
  • Communicate with other devices on the same network
  • Avoid physical cables (Ethernet)

📌 In simple terms:

Wi-Fi = wireless version of Ethernet

docs.title: 2. Wi-Fi vs Internet (Very Important!)
docs.text:
Many beginners confuse these two concepts.

Term Meaning Wi-Fi A wireless connection between your device and a local network Internet The global network of networks

💡 You can have:

  • Wi-Fi without Internet (local network only)
  • Internet without Wi-Fi (wired connection)

Example:

  • Your laptop connects to a router via Wi-Fi
  • The router connects to the Internet via fiber or cable

docs.title: 3. Basic Wi-Fi Components
docs.text: A typical Wi-Fi setup includes:

docs.title: 1️⃣ Router (Core Device)
docs.text:
• Sends and receives Wi-Fi signals
  • Connects your local network to the Internet
  • Usually called a Wi-Fi router

docs.title: 2️⃣ Access Point (AP)
docs.text:
• A device that provides Wi-Fi coverage
  • Home routers usually include an AP
  • In offices, APs may be separate devices

docs.title: 3️⃣ Client Devices
docs.text:
• Phones
  • Laptops
  • Tablets
  • Smart TVs
  • IoT devices

docs.title: 4. How Wi-Fi Works (High Level)
docs.text:
1. The router creates a wireless network
  2. Your device searches for available Wi-Fi networks
  3. You select a network (SSID) and enter a password
  4. Data is transmitted via radio waves
  5. The router forwards traffic to the Internet

📡 Wi-Fi uses radio frequencies, not cables.

docs.title: 5. What Is an SSID?
docs.text:
SSID = Service Set Identifier

It is simply the Wi-Fi network name you see.

Examples:

  • Home_WiFi
  • CoffeeShop_Free
  • GL-MT3000

📌 Multiple routers can broadcast different SSIDs in the same area.

docs.title: 6. Wi-Fi Frequency Bands
docs.text: Wi-Fi works on different frequency bands:

docs.title: 2.4 GHz
docs.text:
• Longer range
  • Slower speed
  • More interference

docs.title: 5 GHz
docs.text:
• Shorter range
  • Faster speed
  • Less interference

docs.title: 6 GHz (Wi-Fi 6E / 7)
docs.text:
• Very fast
  • Very clean spectrum
  • Short range
  • Requires newer devices
Band Range Speed Interference 2.4 GHz Long Low High 5 GHz Medium High Medium 6 GHz Short Very High Low

docs.title: 7. Wi-Fi Standards (802.11)
docs.text:
Wi-Fi versions are defined by IEEE 802.11 standards.

Marketing Name Standard Typical Speed Wi-Fi 4 802.11n Up to ~600 Mbps Wi-Fi 5 802.11ac Up to ~3.5 Gbps Wi-Fi 6 802.11ax Faster + lower latency Wi-Fi 6E 802.11ax (6 GHz) Even faster Wi-Fi 7 802.11be Ultra-high speed

📌 Newer Wi-Fi = better speed, efficiency, and stability.

docs.title: Common Security Types
docs.text:
Type Status Open (No password) ❌ Unsafe WEP ❌ Broken WPA ⚠️ Old WPA2 ✅ Acceptable WPA3 ✅ Recommended

📌 Always use WPA2 or WPA3 with a strong password.

docs.title: 9. Wi-Fi Password vs Router Password
docs.text:
These are different:

Password Type Purpose Wi-Fi password Connect devices to Wi-Fi Router admin password Configure the router

⚠️ Never leave the router admin password as default.

docs.title: 10. Common Wi-Fi Problems (and Why They Happen)
Slow Wi-Fi
docs.text:
• Too many devices
  • Weak signal
  • Interference
  • Old router

docs.title: Weak Signal
docs.text:
• Walls and floors block signals
  • Router placed too far away

docs.title: Frequent Disconnections
docs.text:
• Overlapping channels
  • Power-saving settings
  • Poor firmware

docs.title: 11. Basic Wi-Fi Optimization Tips
docs.text:
✔ Place router in a central location

✔ Use 5 GHz when close to the router

✔ Update router firmware

✔ Change default SSID and password

✔ Avoid placing router near microwaves or metal objects

docs.title: 12. Wi-Fi vs Ethernet
docs.text:
Feature Wi-Fi Ethernet Speed Medium–High High Stability Medium Very High Mobility Excellent None Latency Higher Lower

📌 For gaming, servers, and NAS → Ethernet is better

📌 For phones and laptops → Wi-Fi is more convenient

docs.title: 13. Real-World Example (Home Network)
docs.text:
[ Internet ]
     |
[ Modem ]
     |
[ Wi-Fi Router ]  )))))  Phone
                  )))))  Laptop
                  )))))  Tablet

All devices share one Internet connection via Wi-Fi.

docs.title: 14. What to Learn Next
docs.text:
If you want to go deeper:

  • IP addresses
  • DHCP
  • NAT
  • Channels and interference
  • Mesh Wi-Fi systems
  • Wi-Fi sniffing and troubleshooting tools

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• Wi-Fi is wireless local networking
  • It is not the Internet itself
  • Router + AP + clients form a Wi-Fi network
  • Frequency bands and standards affect performance
  • Security matters—use WPA2/WPA3
